question: Among community-dwelling adults aged 65 and older without visual complaints, does routine vision screening compared with no screening improve visual outcomes such as visual acuity or self-reported visual problems? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The inclusion of a visual screening component in the assessment did not result in improvements in self reported visual problems (pooled odds ratio 1.04:95% confidence interval 0.89 to 1.22).
content.source_2: Randomized community-based trials reported that adding routine vision screening to geriatric assessments significantly reduced the odds of self-reported visual difficulties (pooled odds ratio 0.78, 95% confidence interval 0.66 to 0.92).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Screening of asymptomatic older people in the community is not justified on present evidence.
content.source_4: Synthesis of cluster-randomized studies in adults aged 70 years and older found clinically meaningful gains in near-vision acuity and reading speed at 6â€“12 months after implementing community screening programs, supporting routine screening of asymptomatic seniors.
